text: Testimony of
label: HH1

text: Blake Gerard
label: HH1

text: Before the U.S. House of Representatives
label: HH1

text: Committee on Agriculture
label: BODY

text: Hearing to Review the Future of U.S. Farm Policy and the Formulation of the 2012 Farm Bill
label: BODY

text: Galesburg, Illinois
label: HH1

text: March 23, 2012
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: HH2

text: Chairman Lucas, Ranking Member Peterson, and Members of the Committee, thank you for
label: BODY

text: holding this hearing concerning farm policy and the 2012 farm bill.  I appreciate the opportunity
label: BODY

text: to offer testimony on farm policy from the perspective of a diversified grain producer.
label: BODY

text: My name is Blake Gerard.  I raise rice, soybeans, wheat, and corn in Alexander and Union
label: BODY

text: counties in southern Illinois and I have been farming on my own now for 16 years.  I am the
label: BODY

text: fourth generation in my family to farm this land and this is my 13th year to farm rice in Illinois.  I
label: BODY

text: am also co-owner in a seed conditioning facility that does contract seed production,
label: BODY

text: conditioning, packaging & warehousing.  All of our soybeans are raised for seed along with
label: BODY

text: about 75% of our rice. In addition to my farm and seed business, I also serve as the
label: BODY

text: commissioner for the East Cape Girardeau/Clear Creek Levee & Drainage District, the Illinois
label: BODY

text: Crop Improvement Association and am a member of the USA Rice Producers’ Group Board of
label: BODY

text: Directors.
label: BODY

text: Importance of Agriculture and Cost-Effective Farm Policy
label: HH2

text: U.S. agriculture shares a certain amount of pride for what we do for the nation’s economy.
label: BODY

text: Agriculture still matters.
label: BODY

text: Over the course of the current economic downturn, here is an excerpt of what objective
label: BODY

text: sources ranging from the Federal Reserve to The Wall Street Journal had to say about what
label: BODY

text: America’s farmers and ranchers have been doing to help get our nation back on track and
label: BODY

text: people back to work:
label: BODY

text: “In 2010, rural America was at the forefront of the economic recovery… “[R]ising exports of
label: BODY

text: farm commodities and manufactured goods spurred job growth and income gains in rural
label: BODY

text: communities…If recent history holds true, rural America could lead U.S. economic gains in
label: BODY

text: 2011.”  Federal Reserve of Kansas City, 2010 report.
label: BODY

text: "Growers' improved lot is rippling out to other industries."  The Wall Street Journal, October 12,
label: BODY

text: We read the same kinds of reports during the last recession when the manufacturing sector
label: BODY

text: was in crisis:
label: BODY

text: “Farm Belt Is Becoming a Driver for Overall Economy…The present boom is proving that
label: BODY

text: agriculture still matters in the U.S. Rising farm incomes are helping to ease the blow of the loss
label: BODY

text: of manufacturing jobs in Midwest states…‘The farm sector is a significant source of strength for
label: BODY

text: the U.S. economy,’ says Sung Won Sohn, chief economist of Wells Fargo Bank…Although
label: BODY

text: farmers themselves are a tiny part of the population, they have an outsize impact on the
label: BODY

text: economy because farming is such an expensive enterprise. A full-time Midwest grain farmer
label: BODY

text: often owns millions of dollars of equipment and land, and spends hundreds of thousands of
label: BODY

text: dollars annually on supplies.”  The Wall Street Journal, December 17, 2003.
label: BODY

text: And, for those old enough to remember the 1980s, publications such as The Economist recalled
label: BODY

text: the impact on the rest of the economy when agriculture was not doing well:
label: BODY

text: “The 1990s were so good [for Chicago] partly because the 1980s had been so bad.  ‘Everything
label: BODY

text: that could possibly have gone wrong did’ says William Testa, the senior economist at the
label: BODY

text: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.  The region was hit by a crushing combination of high energy
label: BODY

text: prices, a strong dollar, high interest rates, and a farm recession.”  The Economist, May 12, 2001
label: BODY

text: Last year alone, U.S. farmers and ranchers spent nearly $320 billion in communities across the
label: BODY

text: country to produce agriculture products valued at some $410 billion.  Put in perspective, the
label: BODY

text: value of total U.S. agriculture production was greater than the 2010 GDP of all but 25 nations,
label: BODY

text: and total production cost was greater than all but 28.  And, according to the Department of
label: BODY

text: Agriculture, U.S. agriculture is expected to positively contribute $26.5 billion to the U.S. balance
label: BODY

text: of trade in fiscal year 2012 after having contributed over $40 billion just the year before.
label: BODY

text: And, one of the reasons we are here today, I expect, is because while U.S. agriculture is critically
label: BODY

text: important to America, farm policy is also critically important to U.S. agriculture.
label: BODY

text: Without farm policy, U.S. producers would be unilaterally exposed to global markets distorted
label: BODY

text: by withering high foreign subsidies and tariffs, and have no comprehensive safety net.  In fact,
label: BODY

text: DTB & Associates issued a report last fall, similar to the study on tariffs and subsidies developed
label: BODY

text: and maintained by Texas Tech University (http://www.depts.ttu.edu/ceri/index.aspx.), which
label: BODY

text: found that:
label: BODY

text: “U.S. subsidies…have dropped to very low levels in recent years.  In the meantime, there has
label: BODY

text: been a major increase in subsidization among advanced developing countries… Since the
label: BODY

text: countries involved are major producers and consumers of agricultural products, the trade-
label: BODY

text: distorting effects of the subsidies are being felt globally. However, because the run-up in
label: BODY

text: subsidies is a recent development, and because countries have not reported the new programs
label: BODY

text: to the WTO or have failed in their notifications to calculate properly the level of support, the
label: BODY

text: changes have attracted little attention. We believe that when trade officials examine these
label: BODY

text: developments, they will discover clear violations of WTO commitments.”
label: BODY

text: This aggressive increase in foreign subsides and tariffs might also explain why foreign
label: BODY

text: competitors worked to derail WTO Doha Round negotiations, causing then Chairmen and
label: BODY

text: Ranking Members of the Senate Finance Committee and House Ways & Means Committee to
label: BODY

text: register their opposition to pursuing  a lopsided agreement against the U.S. interests:
label: BODY

text: “Since the WTO Doha Round was launched in 2001, we have supported the administration’s
label: BODY

text: efforts to achieve a balanced outcome that would provide meaningful new market access for
label: BODY

text: U.S. agricultural products…particularly from developed and key emerging markets.
label: BODY

text: Unfortunately, the negotiating texts currently on the table would provide little if any new
label: BODY

text: market access for U.S. goods, and important developing countries are demanding even further
label: BODY

text: concessions from the United States.”  Ways & Means Committee Chairman and Ranking
label: BODY

text: Member Rangel and McCrery and Finance Committee Chairman and Ranking Member Baucus
label: BODY

text: and Grassley.
label: BODY

text: Moreover, while many successfully negotiated trade agreements have promised market access
label: BODY

text: gains for agriculture, much of what was promised has yet to materialize or is continually
label: BODY

text: threatened by artificial sanitary, phytosanitary (SPS) and other non-tariff barriers.   This is why
label: BODY

text: programs such as the Market Access Program and Foreign Market Development Program are of
label: BODY

text: vital concern to the rice industry and must be reauthorized in the 2012 farm bill.  It has not
label: BODY

text: gone unnoticed that budget reductions currently being considered (such as the elimination of
label: BODY

text: the Direct Payment) will result in a dollar for dollar loss in farm income.  Producers must be
label: BODY

text: provided the tools not only to attack these obstacles to trade but to increase exports through
label: BODY

text: market promotion and thereby increase farm income through increased open and fair trade.
label: BODY

text: But, beyond even these barriers that are imposed by foreign competitors are barriers to exports
label: BODY

text: imposed in whole or in part by the U.S. government.  For example, rice was completely
label: BODY

text: excluded from the free trade agreement negotiated with South Korea, foreclosing for the
label: BODY

text: foreseeable future any new market access for U.S. rice producers in that country.  Iraq, once a
label: BODY

text: top export market for U.S. rice, has instituted restrictive specifications on rice imports that have
label: BODY

text: led to a 77 percent drop in sales of U.S. rice to that country.  In the pending Trans Pacific
label: BODY

text: Partnership (TPP) negotiations, Japan has indicated an interest in joining.  The U.S. rice industry
label: BODY

text: supports Japan joining the negotiations, but only if additional market access for U.S. rice into
label: BODY

text: Japan is part of the agreement.  Our industry cannot support an agreement where market
label: BODY

text: access for our product is categorically off the negotiating table.  Another market that has the
label: BODY

text: potential to become a top five export market almost immediately is Cuba. Unfortunately, the
label: BODY

text: U.S. government maintains restrictions on our agricultural exports to this country. Cuba was
label: BODY

text: once the number one export market for U.S. rice prior to the embargo and we believe it is
label: BODY

text: potentially a 400,000 to 600,000 ton market if normal commercial agricultural exports are
label: BODY

text: allowed to resume.
label: BODY

text: In total, U.S. rice exports to date for the current marketing year are down 24 percent compared
label: BODY

text: to last year.
label: BODY

text: And, while the rice industry is still a long ways off from having a crop insurance product that is
label: BODY

text: relevant to rice producers, the general need for federal involvement in insuring crops where
label: BODY

text: losses are highly correlated is also obvious, as even the American Enterprise Institute has
label: BODY

text: admitted:
label: BODY

text: “The empirical evidence on the viability of either area-yield or multiple-peril crop insurance
label: BODY

text: seems clear.  When normal commercial loading factors are applied, the premiums required by
label: BODY

text: insurers to offer an actuarially viable private crop insurance contract are sufficiently high to
label: BODY

text: reduce the demand for such contracts to zero…Thus, private markets for multiple-peril crop
label: BODY

text: insurance are almost surely infeasible, and the weight of the empirical evidence indicates that
label: BODY

text: area-yield contracts are also not commercially viable…”  American Enterprise Institute, “The
label: BODY

text: Economics of Crop Insurance and Disaster Aid, 1995.
label: BODY

text: Fortunately, for the American taxpayer, in addition to all of these justifications on why we have
label: BODY

text: a farm policy in this country, we can add to the list at least one more reason:  farm policy is
label: BODY

text: cost-effective.
label: BODY

text: In fact, U.S. farm policy has operated under budget for over a decade and accounts for only one
label: BODY

text: quarter of one percent of the total federal budget.  Not including additional cuts scheduled
label: BODY

text: under sequestration, U.S. farm policy has, to date, been cut by about $18 billion over the past 9
label: BODY

text: years, including in the 2004 and 2010 Standard Reinsurance Agreements (SRAs), the FY2006
label: BODY

text: reconciliation package, and the 2008 Farm Bill.
label: BODY

text: In the most recent five years, average funding for U.S. farm policy, based on real funding levels,
label: BODY

text: including crop insurance, was $12.9 billion per year, which is 28% less than the previous five-
label: BODY

text: year average of $17.9 billion and 31% less than the average of $18.8 billion that incurred in the
label: BODY

text: preceding five years.  In the current year, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that
label: BODY

text: crop insurance policy will cost slightly more than the current commodity policies.  And
label: BODY

text: according to CBO projections for the next 10 years the estimated annual cost for commodity
label: BODY

text: policy in the farm bill is $6.6 billion on average (before the expected reductions are made as
label: BODY

text: part of this farm bill process), while the estimated annual cost for crop insurance policy is $8.8
label: BODY

text: billion on average.  With the current suite of crop insurance policies not working effectively for
label: BODY

text: rice producers, this puts our industry at a further disadvantage and highlights the need to
label: BODY

text: maintain an effective commodity policy in the farm bill that will work for rice.
label: BODY

text: Funding of that portion of farm policy that assists rice producers has declined from $1.2 billion
label: BODY

text: a decade ago to about $400 million annually, with this amount largely reflecting Direct
label: BODY

text: Payments.
label: BODY

text: Meanwhile, U.S. consumers are paying less than 10% of disposable income on food, less than
label: BODY

text: consumers in any other nation.
label: BODY

text: This is why I believe so firmly that future cuts must focus on areas of the budget outside of farm
label: BODY

text: policy that have not yet contributed to deficit reduction yet comprise a significant share of the
label: BODY

text: federal budget.  This is also why I would urge lawmakers to reject cuts to U.S. farm policy that
label: BODY

text: would exceed the level specified by the House and Senate Agriculture Committee Chairs and
label: BODY

text: Ranking Members in their letter to the Joint Committee on Deficit Reduction last fall.
label: BODY

text: 2008 Farm Bill Review
label: HH2

text: The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (the Farm Bill) continued the traditional mix of
label: BODY

text: policies consisting of the non-recourse marketing loan, loan deficiency payments, and the direct
label: BODY

text: and counter cyclical payments.  The farm bill also included the addition of Average Crop
label: BODY

text: Revenue Election (ACRE) as an alternative to counter cyclical payments for producers who
label: BODY

text: agree to a reduction in direct payments and marketing loan benefits.  The bill also added
label: BODY

text: Supplemental Revenue Assurance (SURE) as a standing disaster assistance supplement to
label: BODY

text: federal crop insurance.
label: BODY

text: The 2008 Farm Bill made very substantial changes to the payment eligibility provisions,
label: BODY

text: establishing an aggressive adjusted gross income (AGI) means test and, albeit unintended by
label: BODY

text: Congress, resulting in the very significant tightening of “actively engaged” requirements for
label: BODY

text: eligibility. USDA was still in the process of implementing many of the provisions of the 2008
label: BODY

text: Farm Bill in 2010, and the final payment eligibility rules were only announced in January of that
label: BODY

text: same year, a mere two years ago.  As a consequence, we are still adjusting to the many changes
label: BODY

text: contained in the current farm bill, even as Congress considers the 2012 farm bill.
label: BODY

text: Regarding ACRE and SURE, frankly, neither policy has proved much value to rice farmers.
label: BODY

text: Specifically, in the first year of ACRE signup, only 8 rice farms representing less than 900 acres
label: BODY

text: were enrolled nationwide.  With changes, this revenue program may provide more value for
label: BODY

text: some rice growing regions like California. And SURE has provided little, if any, assistance to rice
label: BODY

text: producers, including those producers in the Mid South who suffered significant monetary losses
label: BODY

text: in 2009 due to heavy rains and flooding occurring prior to and during harvest, or the significant
label: BODY

text: losses last year as a result of spring flooding in the Mid South.  SURE’s inability to provide
label: BODY

text: disaster assistance for such catastrophic events further highlights the continuing gap in
label: BODY

text: available programs designed to help producers manage or alleviate their risk.
label: BODY

text: Regarding the traditional mix of farm policies, the nonrecourse marketing loan, loan deficiency
label: BODY

text: payment, and countercyclical payments have not yet provided payments to rice farmers under
label: BODY

text: the 2008 Farm Bill.  The new price paradigm has, as a practical matter, greatly limited the
label: BODY

text: protections afforded to producers under these farm policy features.  In fact, if the protections
label: BODY

text: provided were ever to trigger for rice farmers, the protections would help stem some of the
label: BODY

text: economic losses but, frankly, not enough to keep most rice farms in business through even a
label: BODY

text: single year of severely low market prices.
label: BODY

text: As such, whatever its imperfections, the Direct Payment alone has assisted rice producers in
label: BODY

text: meeting the ongoing and serious price and production perils of farming today.
label: BODY

text: For rice producers, as for most other producers, the existing levels of price protection have
label: BODY

text: simply not kept pace with the significant increases in production costs, costs such as energy and
label: BODY

text: fertilizer that are exacerbated by escalating government regulations.  It is for this reason that
label: BODY

text: rice farmers believe strengthening farm policies in the 2012 Farm Bill would be helpful in
label: BODY

text: ensuring that producers have the ability to adequately manage their risks and access needed
label: BODY

text: credit.
label: BODY

text: Crop Insurance
label: HH2

text: Risk management products offered under Federal Crop Insurance have been of very limited
label: BODY

text: value to rice producers to date due to a number of factors, including artificially depressed
label: BODY

text: actual production history (APH) guarantees, which I understand is also a problem for many
label: BODY

text: other producers; high premium costs for a relatively small insurance guarantee; and the fact
label: BODY

text: that the risks associated with rice production are unique from the risks of producing many
label: BODY

text: other major crops.
label: BODY

text: For example, since rice is a flood-irrigated crop, drought conditions rarely result in significant
label: BODY

text: yield losses as growers simply pump additional irrigation water to maintain moisture levels to
label: BODY

text: achieve relatively stable yields.  However, drought conditions do result in very substantial
label: BODY

text: production cost increases as a result of pumping additional water.  As such, what rice farmers
label: BODY

text: need from federal crop insurance are products that will help protect against increased
label: BODY

text: production and input costs, particularly for energy and energy-related inputs.  For example,
label: BODY

text: fuel, fertilizer, and other energy related inputs represent about 70 percent of total variable
label: BODY

text: costs.
label: BODY

text: In this vein, many in the rice industry have been working for over the past four years now to
label: BODY

text: develop a new generation of crop insurance products that might provide more meaningful risk
label: BODY

text: management tools for rice producers in protecting against sharp, upward spikes in input costs.
label: BODY

text: I serve on a rice industry task force that has been working to develop and improve crop
label: BODY

text: insurance products for rice, and although the objective was to gain approval from the Risk
label: BODY

text: Management Agency (RMA) of at least two new products that could be available to growers in
label: BODY

text: time for the 2012 crop year, this has not materialized.  But, it is important to stress that even if
label: BODY

text: these products had become available this year, we do not believe that they would have put rice
label: BODY

text: producers anywhere near on par with other crops in terms of the relevance that crop insurance
label: BODY

text: has as a risk management tool.
label: BODY

text: As such, rice producers enter the 2012 farm bill debate at a very serious disadvantage, having
label: BODY

text: only a single farm policy that effectively works and that farm policy being singled out for
label: BODY

text: elimination.
label: BODY

text: 2012 Farm Bill
label: HH2

text: With the foregoing as a backdrop, the U.S. rice industry developed a set of farm policy priorities
label: BODY

text: in September of last year to guide us during consideration of the 2012 Farm Bill.  The U.S. rice
label: BODY

text: industry is unified in its firm belief that farm policy designed to support a strong and dynamic
label: BODY

text: U.S. agriculture sector is absolutely vital.  We also believe that the planting flexibility provided
label: BODY

text: under the 1996 Farm Bill and the countercyclical policies that have been in place for more than
label: BODY

text: a decade now have served this nation and its farmers well.  In particular, as we noted earlier,
label: BODY

text: the 1996 Farm Bill’s Direct Payments have provided critical help to rice farmers – offering
label: BODY

text: capital farmers could tailor to their unique needs.  We are very proud to stand by this farm
label: BODY

text: policy.
label: BODY

text: However, given budget pressures and other considerations facing Congress that have caused
label: BODY

text: policymakers to consider altering this approach in favor of more directed and conditioned
label: BODY

text: assistance, we developed the following priorities:
label: BODY

text:  First, we believe the triggering mechanism for assistance should be updated to provide
label: BODY

text: tailored and reliable help should commodity prices decline below today’s production
label: BODY

text: costs, and should include a floor or reference price to protect in multi-year low price
label: BODY

text: scenarios.
label: BODY

text:  Second, as payments would only be made in loss situations, payment limits and means
label: BODY

text: tests for producers should be eliminated.
label: BODY

text:  Third, federal crop insurance should be improved to provide more effective risk
label: BODY

text: management for rice in all production regions, beginning with the policy development
label: BODY

text: process.
label: BODY

text: More specifically relative to each of these points, we believe that:
label: BODY

text: Price Protection is a Must
label: HH2

text: Given price volatility for rice is the primary risk producers face that they do not have other good
label: BODY

text: means of protecting against, with price fluctuations largely driven by global supply and
label: BODY

text: demand;  given rice is one of the most protected and sensitive global commodities in trade
label: BODY

text: negotiations, thus limiting access to a number of key markets; given costs of production have
label: BODY

text: risen to a point where the current $6.50 (loan rate)/$10.50 (target price) assistance triggers are
label: BODY

text: largely irrelevant, we believe the first priority should be to concentrate on increasing the prices
label: BODY

text: or revenue levels at which farm policy would trigger so that it is actually meaningful to
label: BODY

text: producers, and would reliably trigger should prices decline sharply.
label: BODY

text: The reference price for rice should be increased to $13.98/cwt ($6.30/bu).  This level would
label: BODY

text: more closely reflect the significant increases in production costs for rice.  And we believe this
label: BODY

text: reference price should be a component of both the price-loss policy and the revenue-loss policy
label: BODY

text: to ensure downside price protection.
label: BODY

text: Options for Different Production Regions
label: HH2

text: In addition, there should be true options for producers that recognize that a one-size-fits-all
label: BODY

text: approach to farm policy does not work effectively for all crops or even the same crop such as
label: BODY

text: rice in different production regions.
label: BODY

text: In the Mid-south and Gulf Coast production regions, a price-based loss policy is viewed as being
label: BODY

text: most effective in meeting the risk management needs of producers.  Specifically, this policy
label: BODY

text: should include a price protection level that is more relevant to current cost of production; paid
label: BODY

text: on planted acres or percentage of planted acres; paid on more current yields; and take into
label: BODY

text: account the lack of effective crop insurance policies for rice.
label: BODY

text: In the California production region, although the existing revenue-based policy still does not
label: BODY

text: provide effective risk management, efforts to analyze modifications which will increase its
label: BODY

text: effectiveness continue.  Since rice yields are highly correlated between the farm, county, crop
label: BODY

text: reporting district, and state levels, we believe the revenue plan should be administered for rice
label: BODY

text: at either the county or crop reporting district level to reflect this situation rather than lowering
label: BODY

text: guarantee levels to use farm level yields.  By setting loss triggers that reflect local marketing
label: BODY

text: conditions, delivering support sooner, and strengthening revenue guarantees that account for
label: BODY

text: higher production costs as well as the absence of effective crop insurance, California rice
label: BODY

text: producers are hopeful that an effective revenue program can be developed.
label: BODY

text: While I have focused on the need for a choice for rice producers in different regions, this also
label: BODY

text: applies for producers of most other grains.  I support having policy options available for corn,
label: BODY

text: soybeans, and wheat, which I produce, and believe that both a price-based policy and a
label: BODY

text: revenue-based policy should be offered as options for these crops.
label: BODY

text: Whatever is done should be plain and bankable.  The current SURE has too many factors and is
label: BODY

text: not tailored to the multiple business risks producers face — it is not plain.  The current ACRE,
label: BODY

text: while offering improved revenue-based protection, is complicated by requiring two loss
label: BODY

text: triggers; providing payments nearly two years after a loss; and provides no minimum price
label: BODY

text: protection — it is not bankable.  The marketing loan and target prices are plain and bankable —
label: BODY

text: unfortunately the trigger prices are no longer relevant to current costs and prices.
label: BODY

text: Whatever is done should be tailored and defendable.  We believe it makes sense to provide
label: HH2

text: assistance when factors beyond the producer's control create losses for producers. We
label: BODY

text: generally think more tailored farm policies are more defendable.   For this reason, we like the
label: BODY

text: thought of updating bases and yields or applying farm policies to planted acres/current
label: BODY

text: production and their triggering based on prices or revenue, depending on the option a
label: BODY

text: producer chooses.  However, policy choices should not result in severe regional distortions in
label: BODY

text: commodity policy budget baselines from which reauthorized commodity policies must be
label: BODY

text: developed.
label: BODY

text: Whatever is done should be built to withstand a multi-year low price scenario. Whether in a
label: HH2

text: revenue-based plan, or a price-based plan, reference prices should protect producer income in
label: BODY

text: a relevant way in the event of a series of low price years.  Ideally, this minimum could move
label: BODY

text: upward over time should production costs also increase, this being of particular concern in the
label: BODY

text: current regulatory environment.
label: BODY

text: Whatever is done should not dictate or distort planting decisions.  Direct payments are
label: HH2

text: excellent in this regard.  SURE or similar whole farm aggregations tend to discourage
label: BODY

text: diversification, which could be a problem for crops like rice.  Any commodity specific farm
label: BODY

text: policy that is tied to planted acres must be designed with extreme care so as to not create
label: BODY

text: payment scenarios that incentivize farmers to plant for a farm policy.  Whatever is done should
label: BODY

text: accommodate history and economics and allow for proportional reductions to the baseline
label: BODY

text: among commodities.  Some commodities are currently more reliant on countercyclical farm
label: BODY

text: policies (ACRE/CCP) while others are receiving only Direct Payments in the baseline.  Generally,
label: BODY

text: the least disruptive and fairest way to achieve savings across commodities would be to apply a
label: BODY

text: percentage reduction to each commodity baseline and restructure any new policy within the
label: BODY

text: reduced baseline amounts.
label: BODY

text: There have been concerns raised about higher reference prices distorting planting decisions
label: BODY

text: and resulting in significant acreage shifts including for rice.  We are unaware of any analysis
label: BODY

text: that shows significant acreage shifts resulting from the reference price levels included in the
label: BODY

text: 2011 Farm Bill package.  In fact, for rice specifically, a reference price of $13.98/cwt that is paid
label: BODY

text: on historic CCP payment yields and on 85% of planted acres results in a reference price level
label: BODY

text: well below our average cost of production, so I find it hard to imagine why someone would
label: BODY

text: plant simply due to this policy given these levels.
label: BODY

text: Pay Limits/Eligibility Tests Should Be Eliminated
label: HH2

text: The likely outcome of new farm policy is that it will provide less certainty for the producer (a
label: BODY

text: likely decrease or elimination of Direct Payments).  Since it will likely be designed to provide
label: BODY

text: assistance only in loss situations, the second priority is that the policy should not be limited
label: BODY

text: based on arbitrary dollar limits. Assistance should be tailored to the size of loss.  A producer
label: BODY

text: should not be precluded from participating in a farm policy because of past income experience.
label: BODY

text: Any internal limits on assistance should be percentage-based (i.e. 25% of an expected crop
label: BODY

text: value) and not discriminate based on the size of farm.
label: BODY

text: Crop Insurance Should Be Maintained and Improved
label: HH2

text: Although crop insurance does not currently work as well for rice as it does for other crops, the
label: BODY

text: third priority would be to improve availability and effectiveness of crop insurance for rice as an
label: BODY

text: available option.  I would also support improvement to the product development processes (we
label: BODY

text: have struggled with two 508(h) submissions for over 4 years and are still not completed with
label: BODY

text: the process), and to the APH system such that any farmer's insurable yield (pre-deductible)
label: BODY

text: would be reflective of what that farmer actually expects to produce.  In no case should the crop
label: BODY

text: insurance tools, which are purchased by the producer, be encumbered with
label: BODY

text: environmental/conservation regulation or other conditions that fall outside the scope of
label: BODY

text: insurance.
label: BODY

text: 2011 Budget Control Act Efforts
label: HH2

text: Although the details of the 2011 Farm Bill package that was prepared by the House and Senate
label: BODY

text: Agriculture Committees in response to the Budget Control Act were not disclosed, based on
label: BODY

text: discussions and reports we believe that that package at least represents a good framework on
label: BODY

text: which to build the 2012 Farm Bill. The 2011 package included a choice of risk management
label: BODY

text: tools that producers can tailor to the risks on their own farms, providing under each of those
label: BODY

text: options more meaningful price protection that is actually relevant to today’s production costs
label: BODY

text: and prices.  It also included provisions to improve crop insurance and expedite product
label: BODY

text: development for underserved crops such as rice.
label: BODY

text: We are concerned that effective support for rice producers under the price-based option was
label: BODY

text: set well below cost of production that late changes to the revenue-based option minimized its
label: BODY

text: potential as an effective risk management tool for rice producers, and that pay limits and AGI
label: BODY

text: rules would still serve as an arbitrary constraint upon U.S. competitiveness, globally.  Still, even
label: BODY

text: with these areas for improvement, the U.S. rice industry very much appreciates the Members
label: BODY

text: and staff who put enormous time and effort into what we believe represents a good blue print
label: BODY

text: for ongoing Farm Bill deliberations and we thank you.
label: BODY

text: Again, thank you for this opportunity to offer my testimony.  We certainly look forward to
label: BODY

text: working with you on an effective 2012 Farm Bill we can all be proud of.
label: BODY
